content: Open data is a redaction in the eyes of city officials and lawyers
Are you exposing the city to a liability if you open up data? (risk averse)
The nail that sticks out gets pounded down
Historically, Albuquerque is a place of 'behind the fence' innovation
Senior Affairs / Family Community Services don't tell the community about their programs because they're afraid they will succeed and they might not be able to handle the intake, making them look bad
ShareNM is a curator of information, a wikipedia, an information commons
Indigenous communities want indigenous solutions
If you want to go fast, go alone, if you want to go far, go with others

10+ re-designs in the last 20 years. Website doesn't support Navajo language. More mobile usage on weekends. How does the community ask for help? What are the key words people are using? What are the nodes that should be shared?
70% of Albuquerque's population is working poor
Your problem may have a legal component
people are fearful to learn about their rights because they see it as an immigration trap
25% of clients have mental illness (bi-polar)
Little Brother mentality
We're not good at telling our own story
Most students are in need of access to non-academic resources (anti-poverty resources, standard referral system.
You don't know what you don't know
How can I learn to sell the rose I bought for a dollar and sell it for $2?
Where do things need to be pushed apart or brought together
State workers don't know the reality of what happening on the ground
Our workers don't want to bite the hand that feeds you
State programs ultimately repurpose the same shitty programs
